abstract.p: Mass and energy exchange processes near the in-cylinder walls have become increasingly important for internal combustion engine research and development. Heat-transfer and fuel-deposition processes are not well enough understood to fully predict their magnitude and temporal and spatial variation. To a large extent, improvements in modeling are limited because of a lack of experimental guidance on the dynamics of boundary-layer flows in engines. High-speed particle image velocimetry and micro particle image velocimetry were used to study the boundary-layer flow field at the cylinder head of a motored internal combustion engine for three different engine speeds (400, 800 and 1100 r/min). Velocity measurements were taken throughout the compression stroke and the beginning of the expansion stroke, and comparisons to the frequently used law-of-the-wall were made.

The low-resolution particle image velocimetry images showed that the average bulk flow maintained a tumble flow throughout the compression and expansion strokes and velocities scaled with engine speed. Adequate spatial resolution of the boundary-layer flow required the use of high-resolution (micro particle image velocimetry) measurements which showed that the log-law does not accurately describe the experimental boundary-layer structure in the outer layer (

The viscous sublayer could not be adequately resolved at 1100 r/min because of the limitations in adequate seeding density near the surface and the resulting loss of data points closest to the wall.

The capability of high-speed particle image velocimetry measurements is demonstrated by the ability to identify and track vortical structures that move through the outer and buffer layers. Future work must address the evolution of such flow structures, along with measurements of temperature, to enable development and validation of boundary-layer models that are not restricted by the assumptions necessary for the law-of-the-wall such as steady bulk flow conditions and properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The flow process in internal combustion (IC) engines plays an important role in improving fuel efficiency and reducing pollutant formation. In this context, the near-wall flow at the cylinder and piston walls becomes more significant for modern engine concepts with higher power densities and lower cylinder volumes. Mass and energy transfer processes in the boundary-layer flows of IC engines have a substantial impact on the heat-transfer characteristics and wall fuel film dynamics. While heat transfer in general is a topic of interest in engine research, it has gained even more attention in the context of premixed compression ignition engines where changes in heat transfer can affect ignition timing. The release of wall fuel deposits is presently discussed as a potential cause of pre-knock, contributing to local enrichment and temperature peaks. Predictive simulations of this region are still limited because typically the spatial resolution to fully describe transport in the boundary layer is not achieved.1 Furthermore, current near-wall models do not capture the impact of transient high-pressure and high-temperature conditions in engines adequately and must therefore be refined.

In general, turbulent boundary layers are characterized by the production of quasi-coherent vortical structures. Robinson2 gives a considerable overview of the research on these structures in steady turbulent boundary layers. Several processes produce vortex structures inside the boundary layers. The most important one is the ejection of low-speed fluid streaks into higher velocity layers in the buffer region. These streaks appear in the near-wall region of the flow and move towards the free stream. To conserve mass, high-speed fluid enters the low-speed layers near the wall at a shallow angle (called sweep).3 This leads to characteristic oscillations that produce vortices in a process known as bursting. Bursting can form different vortex structures with shapes similar to horseshoes or hairpins. These vortices are responsible for an intensive mass and momentum transfer between the inner and the outer layers.

For unsteady boundary layers, like those in IC engines, the structure of the near-wall flow field becomes more complex. Costamagna et al.4 and Kearney et al.5 performed some computational fluid dynamics for oscillatory boundary layers in the laminar and turbulent regime in a channel flow. Their results show that unsteady boundary layers have the same flow structures in the inner layer compared to those detected in the steady boundary layers. Near-wall flows in engines are far more complex, not only because of the geometric differences, but because the outer flow is not constant in pressure, temperature and velocity. However, only a few studies have been performed and thus far, there is a lack of experimental data to support model development and validation of higher resolution dynamic modeling efforts. Here and in the following, we will focus on the flow field in near-wall regions of in-cylinder flows.

Obtaining measurements of the in-cylinder flow field is challenging because of limited access and the complex and unsteady nature of the flow. However, the adoption of modern optical measurement techniques like laser Doppler velocimetry (LDV) and particle image velocimetry (PIV) in engines with optical access can lead to a better understanding of engine flow processes. PIV in particular is of interest since it can deliver flow information in a plane or even a volume.

The first in-cylinder flow field experiments using optical laser-based measurement techniques were performed in the early 1980s and 1990s. Rimai et al.,6 Reuss et al.7 and Rönnbäck et al.8 performed investigations in motored engines, and Nino et al.9 conducted a study in a fired engine. In recent years, high-speed PIV applications for engines have been developed (e.g. Towers and Towers,10 Fajardo and Sick11 and Müller et al.12).
While many experiments on the in-cylinder mean and bulk velocity fields have been conducted, only a few experimental investigations on the near-wall flow field have been performed.

The first attempt to measure the boundary layer in an IC engine was reported by Hall and Bracco13 in 1986. The flow field in a spark ignition (SI) engine was resolved with LDV near the wall throughout portions of the compression and expansion strokes (318–382 crank angle degrees (CAD)) at 1200 r/min for non-firing and firing engine operation. Radial and tangential velocity profiles were measured as close as 0.5 mm and 1.5 mm from the wall, respectively. The velocity profiles exhibited solid body rotation until 10 mm from the wall. At this position, the boundary layer began and the tangential velocity decreased due to momentum diffusion near the wall. The boundary-layer thickness remained nearly constant with increasing compression. The first measured point from the wall (0.5 mm) was not close enough to resolve the boundary layer. At this position, the ensemble average mean velocity was still 90% of the maximum value. The flow field in the firing case was more complex than the non-firing case and had a thinner boundary layer.

Like Hall and Bracco, Foster and Witze14 performed similar experiments using LDV in a different test configuration. Measurements were taken at 300 r/min as close as 60 µm from the cylinder wall with a high and low swirl ratio in firing and non-firing environments. The boundary-layer thickness for crank angles between 340 and 390 CAD for the non-firing case was less than 200 µm for high swirl number and between 700 and 1000 µm for low swirl numbers. For the firing case, the boundary-layer thickness was constant at 600 µm for low and high swirl conditions. The turbulence intensity increased for the non-firing cases and decreased for firing cases in the regions close to the wall.

Pierce et al.15 investigated the near-wall velocity field in a four-valve engine using LDV and PIV. Measurements were taken throughout the compression stroke for different crank angles before and after top dead center (TDC) at engine speeds of 750 r/min and 1500 r/min. Data was acquired up to 50 µm from the cylinder head. The bulk velocity followed the swirl direction (tangential velocity) up to 440 CAD, just before exhaust valve opening. After valve opening, large flow variations near the surface were identified. Furthermore, the authors found a two-dimensional surface flow near the cylinder head. The flow had a radial component towards the center of the cylinder, especially during the compression stroke. Nevertheless, a boundary layer was not identified.

The most recent experimental results on boundary layers in IC engines were published by Alharbi and Sick,16 who presented the first two-dimensional measurements of the boundary-layer flow. This investigation was conducted in the boundary layer at the cylinder head of an optical non-firing four-valve engine at 800 r/min for the whole compression and expansion stroke. Low-resolution PIV experiments and high-resolution micro-PIV (µPIV), as well as particle tracking velocimetry (PTV) experiments were combined to cover the spatial dynamic range needed to resolve the boundary-layer structure. The low-resolution measurement was used to identify the global flow structures near the wall and the impact of the outer flow on the boundary layer. The high-resolution PIV/PTV measurement resolved the boundary-layer profiles at the cylinder head up to 45 µm from the wall and observed sub-millimeter-sized vortex structures. A well-marked boundary layer with a thickness of around 0.7 mm and a free stream velocity of 2 m/s was observed throughout the compression stroke. The flow field near the cylinder head showed strong fluctuation intensities that were on the order of the free stream velocity.

This paper presents high-speed PIV and µPIV measurements of two-dimensional boundary-layer flow fields collected at the cylinder head of a motored engine. Flow measurements were taken for three engine speeds to determine the effect of engine speed on flow behavior. Averaged velocity profiles were analyzed and compared with traditional near-wall flow descriptions. Measurements were conducted in the same engine used in the studies performed by Alharbi and Sick, but the spark plug was removed. The experiment was divided into low-resolution PIV and high-resolution µPIV to resolve the bulk flow and near-wall flow, respectively. For both measurements, high-speed image sequences were captured using CMOS (Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor) cameras at repetition rates between 1.2 and 2.4 kHz to follow the evolution of vortex structures and to resolve the boundary-layer flow in time. The low-resolution vector fields were calculated using a PIV cross-correlation algorithm (DaVis, LaVision). The high-resolution data were independently processed with a PIV cross-correlation method and a PIV sum-of-correlation method (both DaVis, LaVision). Both methods provided a vector spacing of 50 µm, but the sum-of-correlation method was able to produce more reliable vectors very close to the wall (<150 µm). With this method, the first vector was located as close as 50 µm away from the wall. Using improved laser sheet optics decreased the light sheet thickness, reduced noise, and increased the spatial resolution in the third dimension in the high-resolution data.

sec.title: Optical engine
sec.p: The flow field near the cylinder head of an optical four-stroke, single-cylinder, spark-ignited direct-injection (SIDI) engine was investigated in this study. The aluminum cylinder head has a pent-roof design and a twin-cam controls four overhead valves. The intake system consists of a bulk flow port and a tangential port that is responsible for swirl production in the cylinder. Both ports were operated fully open, which leads to a dominant in-cylinder tumble flow. Optical access is achieved through the quartz cylinder liner, a piston window and two windows in the cylinder head. Measurements at the cylinder head were taken through the two flat quartz windows inserted on opposite sides of the cylinder head. The piston window provides optical access for the vertically propagating laser sheets. Engine specifications are listed in Table 1 and a schematic of the engine is shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Schematic of the optical SIDI engine.

sec.p: The field-of-view was located between the spark plug and the fuel injector and oriented in the tumble plane. The spark plug was replaced with a spark plug dummy that was flush with the cylinder head surface.

sec.title: Recording setup
sec.p: Silicone oil droplets were added to the intake flow and were illuminated by two Nd:YAG high repetition rate lasers at 532 nm (Quantronix Hawk-II). These lasers achieve high pulse energies at high repetition rates up to 50 kHz. One improvement since Alharbi’s work was that both lasers were modified by the manufacturer to a transverse mode TEM 00 beam profile with a reported quality of M2 = 1.2. This enabled better focusing and, in turn, thinner light sheets than with the multi-mode versions used in previous work. Polarizing optics were used to combine the two linearly polarized beams and a quarterwave plate then turned the combined beams into circularly polarized light.

In addition to the single-mode operation of the laser, the combined beams were passed through a beam homogenizer (lenslet array with re-imaging optics) to form the circular beam into a thin light sheet with a homogenous light intensity distribution. The thickness of the light sheet affects the spatial resolution in the third dimension and the background noise in the image due to scattered light from unfocused particles in the laser sheet plane. The sheet thickness could be reduced to 150 µm compared to about 1 mm used by Alharbi and Sick16
The experiment was divided into a low-resolution PIV and a high-resolution µPIV measurement.

For the low-resolution measurement, a high-speed CMOS camera (Phantom v7.1, Vision Research) equipped with a macro lens (Sigma DG, NA = 0.03125, f # = 16 and working distance 127 mm) was used. The magnification was M = 0.88, the light sheet thickness was 1 mm and the depth-of-field was 2.5 mm.

For the high-resolution measurement, a CMOS camera with a higher dynamic range (14 bit instead of 12 bit) and faster frame rate was used (Phantom v7.3 Vision Research). This camera is able to handle brighter wall reflections encountered during the high-resolution measurements. The camera was connected to a long distance microscope (Questar QM-100) to achieve a smaller field-of-view. The working distance for the optical setup was 168.5 mm with a corresponding microscope magnification of M = 6.95 (f # = 3.5 and NA = 0.142). To increase the spatial resolution in the third dimension, the light sheet thickness was reduced to 150 µm. The corresponding depth-of-field of this setup was 28 µm, and thus was still smaller than the laser sheet thickness.

Silicone oil (Dow Corning 510R) was atomized with a six-jet atomizer (TSI model 9306) to generate seeding particles with 1 µm in diameter. These small droplets were able to follow even small flow structures with high fluctuations. To measure the response time of the droplets in the flow, the Stokes number for various typical engine time scales was determined. In all cases, the calculated Stokes numbers were at least one order of magnitude smaller than one, which confirms that the particles follow the flow faithfully. More information regarding these calculations may be found in Alharbi and Sick.16

In addition to particle lag, the effect of particle velocities induced by temperature gradients (thermophoretic effect) was negligible. According to estimations by Gomez and Rosner,17 the induced velocities (

sec.title: Low- and high-resolution measurements
sec.p: The measurements for this investigation were divided into low- and high-resolution experiments for engines speeds of 400, 800 and 1100 r/min with a swirl number of Rs = 0.8 and a tumble ratio of 0.7. For all measurements, the field-of-view was located in the tumble plane of the cylinder in the region between the intake and exhaust valves (Figure 2). The engine was motored for each experiment to show the basic cylinder flow pattern without the complexities of combustion.

caption.p: Position of the field-of-view at the cylinder head (left: bottom view, right: side view).

sec.title: Low-resolution measurements
sec.p: The overall purpose of the low-resolution experiments was to gain an overview of global flow structures in this area and its impact on the boundary layer. The low-resolution experiment was performed using a high-speed PIV measurement technique. Mie scattering images were recorded from 180 to 420 CAD. Images for later crank angles during the expansion stroke were not used because condensation during the expansion stroke resulted in inaccurate PIV results. The field-of-view was a rectangle of dimensions 11.74 mm × 9.70 mm.

Recording properties such as the camera’s recording frequency/laser frequency, the imaged crank angle frequency, number of recorded cycles, number of individual runs and laser pulse time delay were optimized for each engine speed. These properties and the laser pulse energy measurements can be seen in Table 2.

caption.p: Recording properties for the low-resolution experiment.

sec.p: The recording frequency was constrained by the camera’s maximum frame rate and the requirement to use the full frame. The recording frequency determined the frequency of imaged crank angles for each engine speed. The number of cycles was constrained by the camera’s memory size and how quickly the engine became dirty from seeding particles. Measurements were repeated 3–4 times for each engine speed, and it was ensured that variations between runs were less than cycle-to-cycle fluctuations in the velocities. Typically, the standard deviation, corrected by the Student t-distribution, for the averages at each crank angle are less than 1/3 of the standard deviation for cycle-to-cycle fluctuations.

The time delay was adjusted to meet the requirement for optimizing the particle shift (one quarter of the interrogation window size during one time step18). However, engine flows require many different time delays because of velocity variations throughout the cycle. Another challenge was finding a compromise between the very low velocities close to the wall and the higher velocities in the free stream. The mean piston speed provided a preliminary estimate of the mean flow velocity. For the optimized time delays listed in Table 2, the averaged particle displacement for the compression stroke was between 2 and 6 pixels and decreased to 2–3 pixels during the expansion stroke (for the entire flow field). The maximum averaged particle displacement (6 pixels) occurred at 320 CAD. There were also local variations of the particle displacement between the near-wall (between 0.6 and 2.8 pixels) flow and the bulk flow (1–8 pixels). Like velocity, the fluid density and therefore the seeding density varied throughout the cycle. The recommended seeding density of 5–8 particles per interrogation window was achieved by the middle of the compression stroke. At bottom dead center (BDC), the seeding density decreased to 3–7 particles, but was still high enough for the low-resolution PIV experiment.

sec.title: High-resolution measurements
sec.p: The objective of the high-resolution experiments was to characterize the boundary-layer dynamics and structure. The images were taken for a sub-area of the low-resolution field-of-view (Figure 2). The recording properties for the different engine speeds are summarized in Table 3. The differences in recording rate and number of recorded cycles compared to the low-resolution measurements were due to the change to the Phantom v7.3 for the high-resolution experiments.

caption.p: Recording properties for the high-resolution experiment.

sec.p: One challenge in this experiment was selecting the interrogation window size to balance the averaged particle displacement observed throughout the compression stroke (1–8 pixel). An additional challenge was the low seeding density in the areas close to the wall. There were interrogation windows with less than two particles. Increasing the seeder pressure increased the particle density in the outer flow, but not in the near-wall region. Obtaining adequate seeding density in the near-wall region remains an open issue for PIV near boundaries.

sec.title: Data processing
sec.p: In general, the raw images from both sets of experiments were pre-processed using a high-pass filter to remove noise and other large structures caused by laser reflections from the cylinder wall. Next, cross-correlation methods were used. Finally, a post-processing algorithm, consisting of four subroutines (Q-ratio comparison, median filter, vector fill up, 3 × 3 smoothing filter) was applied to the results of the vector calculation to remove spurious and false vectors.

sec.title: Low-resolution PIV
sec.p: The PIV results for the low-resolution experiments were determined using a multi-pass process to calculate the vector fields in several iterations. The first two passes used 64 × 64 pixel size interrogation windows and were followed by two passes using the final 32 × 32 pixel spot size. The interrogation window overlap in all calculation steps was set to 50%, which yielded to a final grid spacing of 16 pixels. A final vector resolution of 0.31 mm was achieved. However, it is important to note that since the information used in determining a vector stems from a 32 × 32 pixel interrogation window, the actual spatial resolution is closer to that, i.e. 0.62 mm.19

sec.title: High-resolution vector calculation
sec.p: Three different vector calculation methods, PIV, PIV + PTV and PIV sum of correlations (PIV SOC), were used and compared to address the challenges due to the low seeding density close to the wall and the high gradients in the viscous sublayer. The PIV/PTV algorithm is based on the work of Stitou and Riethmuller20 and the PIV SOC algorithm is based on the work of Meinhart et al.21

The averaged results of both the standard PIV and the PIV + PTV hybrid algorithm were comparable, and the velocities in the outer region were similar to the low-resolution vector fields. Difficulties appeared in the flow field closer than 150 µm to the wall. Here, the seeding density was not sufficient for a reliable cross-correlation computation for the PIV method or a regular grid calculation for the PTV method. Therefore, the PIV SOC method was used to identify ensemble averaged velocity profiles in this region. Like for the PIV analysis of the low-resolution images, a multi-pass processing algorithm for the PIV SOC was used on the high-resolution images. The first three passes used a 64 × 64 pixel interrogation window and were followed by two passes using a 32 × 32 pixel window. All passes used 50% overlap. This led to a vector spacing of 50 µm (16 pixel grid) and corresponds to a spatial resolution of 100 µm. The first vector was located 50 µm from the wall.

sec.title: Low-resolution data
sec.p: The results of the low-resolution experiments provided insight on the bulk flow behavior and its impact on the boundary-layer flow. Images of the mean bulk flow from the compression and the beginning of the expansion stroke for an engine speed of 400 r/min may be seen in Figure 3. These images show that the flow maintained the induced tumble motion that produced the flow from the left to the right side in the field-of-view throughout the whole compression stroke. The tumble motion was still present at the beginning of the expansion stroke, but the flow began to move downward as the piston moved toward BDC. Reduced velocities parallel to the wall were observed around 1 mm and closer to the wall. This indicates the presence of a velocity boundary layer. For higher engine speeds, the expected gradient at the wall increased and the spatial resolution of the low-resolution measurement was not sufficient to resolve this structure.

caption.p: Overview of the average flow field (96 cycles) at 400 r/min engine speed shown for selected crank angles (low-resolution measurement), every second vector is shown.

sec.p: The normalized profiles of the ensemble averaged horizontal velocity component (u) and vertical velocity component (v) for each engine speed showed that the bulk flow scales reasonably well with the engine speed (Figure 4 and Figure 5). Given the smooth average flow structures shown in Figure 3, the velocity components were evaluated at a representative monitor point (x = 6 mm, y = 5 mm) in the bulk flow and the profiles were normalized by the mean piston speed (Vp). Spatially averaged data might yield an even stronger agreement amongst all data sets; in particular, the lowest normalized engine speed data did not agree quite as well as the data from the other two speeds.

caption.p: Horizontal velocity component at x=6 / y = 5 mm (error bars show the standard deviation of the sampled runs, every third error bar is shown).
Vertical velocity component at x = 6 / y = 5 mm (error bars show the standard deviation of the sampled runs, every third error bar is shown).

sec.p: At the beginning of compression (180 CAD), u was large and indicated the high momentum of the air entering through the open intake valves. The horizontal velocity decreased rapidly to a local minimum at 200 CAD and then increased due to the upward motion of the piston, reaching a maximum at 330 CAD. As the piston approached TDC, u decreased for the rest of the recorded crank angle range.

The vertical velocity was smaller and behaved differently than the horizontal velocity. From BDC (180 CAD), the v profiles in Figure 5 decayed to a local minimum at 220 CAD. After a small increase, the vertical component decreased to another local minimum. This minimum corresponds to the maximum value of u. While the field-of-view of the current experiments does not show the entire in-cylinder cross section and thus the tumble flow is not visualized completely, the observed flow patterns are consistent with a clockwise tumble flow. The variation in the vertical velocity component then indicates a motion of the tumble core in the horizontal direction.

sec.title: High-resolution data
sec.p: The results of the high-resolution experiment provided information about the flow near the cylinder head. The spatial resolution was increased using the long-distance microscope and enabled the visualization of the boundary-layer structure in much more detail compared to the low-resolution measurements. The discussion here is focused on averaged profiles to identify how well a simple law-of-the-wall model describes the flow. However, as an outlook, the vector field sequence shown in Figure 6 illustrates the power of high-speed flow imaging to resolve sub-millimeter structures that can contribute substantially to energy and mass transfer in the boundary layer. Such details are completely lost during averaging.

caption.p: High-resolution, high-speed PIV measurements reveal the motion of small vortical flow structures within the boundary layer. Selected images taken near the end of intake at 400 r/min are shown here. The wall is located at y=0. Note that these results were determined using a PIV routine for the analysis to obtain individual flow fields.

sec.p: Averaged u profiles show the horizontal velocity component for each measured crank angle position. Phase averaged velocity fields were first determined. Then, u profiles were determined by averaging four adjacent vector columns (a horizontal span of 204 µm) to increase the statistical significance of the velocity vectors close to the wall. This was necessary due to the small seeding density in the near-wall region. The variations between four adjacent vector columns were very small and justified this approach without increasing the error, as already described by Alharbi and Sick.16 The averaged near-wall u profiles are shown in Figure 7 for speeds of 400, 800 and 1100 r/min, respectively. Figure 8 shows the evolution of the velocity for all measured crank angle positions for a representative distance at y=1.5 mm from the surface.

caption.p: Averaged high-resolution horizontal velocity profiles at 400, 800 and 1100 r/min. Data shown were obtained from a sum-of-correlation analysis and are shown for selected crank angle degrees.
The average velocity evolution follows the same trend with crank angle for all engine speeds. Shown here are the profiles at y=1.5 mm.

Velocity gradient at the wall for 400 and 800 r/min varies strongly with crank angle. In particular, it is noteworthy that the gradients increase strongly during the compression stroke and the relative uncertainty is independent of crank angle and evaluated as 13% and 16% for 400 and 800 r/min, respectively.

sec.p: At the beginning of compression (180 CAD), the bulk flow velocities were high, but rapidly decreased (around 200 CAD) before increasing again, reaching a maximum around 300–310 CAD.

The presence of the boundary layer is indicated by the decay in the average velocity u closer to the wall, as seen in Figure 7. The averaged boundary-layer structure in this region is very similar for all recorded crank angles. The experimental boundary layers were compared to the theoretical boundary-layer description provided by the law-of-the-wall, which was developed for steady, fully developed channel flows.3 The law-of-the-wall is used for near-wall flow modeling in IC engines among other models, but none reflect the transient nature of high-pressure, high-temperature conditions in engines, and neither includes the unsteady and not fully developed nature of IC engine boundary layers. But given the widespread use of the law-of-the-wall, a comparison of the experimental data to such model predictions seems useful.

As seen in Figure 10, the log-law (equation (5)) does not adequately describe the velocity profile in the outer parts of the boundary layer. The log-law over predicts the velocity for earlier crank angles (180–260 CAD) for all engine speeds that were investigated. For later crank angles (300–330 CAD), the initial match at the lowest engine speed of 400 r/min gets lost as engine speed increases and at 1100 r/min, the log-law prediction is substantially below the measured data. It has to be noted that it is not really expected that the log-law accurately describes the experimental flow beyond the buffer zone since it was developed for a steady, fully developed channel flow or a flow over a flat plate. Additionally, the law-of-the-wall assumes the bulk flow outside the boundary layer is uniform. However, as indicated by the low-resolution experiment results, the bulk flow velocity within the cylinder changes with the wall distance because of the tumble vortex and other unsteady flow patterns. This affects the behavior in the outer layer of the boundary-layer flow. Finally, the law-of-the-wall describes a two-dimensional flow and does not capture the three-dimensional character of the in-cylinder flow.

The seeding density that can be achieved near the surface restricts the reliability of the velocity data nearest to the wall, or in cases of lowest seeding (higher outer flow velocities in general and 1100 r/min engine operation in particular) even prevents the determination of velocity vectors. In comparison to Alharbi and Sick,16 the light sheet thickness in the present experiments was six times thinner to improve spatial resolution, but accordingly, seeding density issues are thus increased and the results are more noisy. This is clearly a shortcoming of the present data and will have to be addressed in future studies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: High-speed PIV and µPIV were used to study the bulk and boundary-layer flow field near the cylinder head of a motored IC engine for three different engine speeds (400, 800 and 1100 r/min). Velocity measurements were taken throughout the compression stroke and the beginning of the expansion stroke. Boundary-layer velocity profiles were resolved as close as 50 µm away from the wall and allowed the evaluation of the profiles with respect to expectations from the law-of-the-wall. Furthermore, the motion of vortical flow structures could be followed in the high-speed vector field sequences.

The low-resolution images were processed using a standard PIV cross-correlation algorithm to achieve a vector spacing of 0.31 mm, and then the results were ensemble averaged for further analysis. The images showed that the average bulk flow maintained a strong tumble flow throughout the compression and expansion strokes. Additionally, the average bulk flow scaled well with the mean piston speed.

High-resolution data that were processed with a standard cross-correlation algorithm yielded results with a vector spacing of 50 µm. Those flow field images clearly showed the temporal and spatial evolution of vortical structures in the boundary layer. However, at a distance of less than 150 µm from the wall, the seeding density was too low for high-quality PIV analysis. To account for the reduced seeding density, the high-resolution images were processed using a PIV SOC algorithm to obtain higher quality averaged velocity profiles in the viscous sublayer with a vector spacing of 50 µm. The data processed with this method showed that the log-law does not accurately describe the experimental boundary-layer structure in the outer layer (

However, the experimental velocity profiles near the wall (

Furthermore, the thickness of the viscous sublayer decreased as the engine speed increased, but the viscous sublayer could not be resolved with sufficient data points at 1100 r/min because of the reduced thickness and limitations in adequate seeding density near the surface and the resulting loss of data points closest to the wall.

The boundary-layer thicknesses that were observed in this study are within the range of thicknesses measured in other engines in the past using LDV.14 However, generalization of any of those data are not possible because the outer flow in each of the engines studied is different, and the deviation from a steady and uniform velocity outer flow is a root cause for the discrepancy between measurements and the law-of-the-wall. The results presented here show that neither the slope nor the offset of the log-law portion follow the expected constant values typically used with the law-of-the-wall. Rather, experimentally determined values would have to be used to calibrate a boundary-layer model.

To aid the development of predictive engine flow and heat-transfer models, future efforts should be focused on collecting simultaneous velocity and temperature measurements in the near-wall region. Cundy et al.27 have demonstrated the use of laser-induced fluorescence techniques to resolve temperature boundary layers with a high spatial resolution in a flow field. Coupling the velocity and temperature measurements could provide a complete characterization of the physical processes in the boundary layer and contribute to a substantial improvement in heat-transfer models for engines.
